references: Theoretical Features. We analyse BVR-L-SGD for general nonconvex smooth objectives under second-order heterogeneity assumption, which interpolates the heterogeneity of local objectives between the identical case and the extremely non-IID case, and plays a critical role in our nonconvex analysis. The comparison of the communication complexities of our method with the most relevant existing results is given in Table 1. The communication complexity of BVR-L-SGD has a better dependence on ÎµÎµ\varepsilon than minibatch SGD, local SGD and SCAFFOLD. When â„¬â€‹Pâ‰«nâˆ§1/Îµmuch-greater-thanâ„¬ğ‘ƒğ‘›1ğœ€\mathcal{B}P\gg\sqrt{n\wedge 1/\varepsilon} and the second-order heterogeneity Î¶ğœ\zeta of local objectives is small relative to the smoothness Lğ¿L, BVR-L-SGD strictly surpasses minibatch SARAH. Furthermore, BVR-L-SGD is the first method that breaks the barrier of communication complexity 1/Îµ1Îµ1/\varepsilon when local computation budget â„¬â†’âˆâ†’â„¬\mathcal{B}\to\infty, for general smooth nonconvex objectives with small heterogeneity Î¶ğœ\zeta. Importantly, even when the heterogeneity is high, the communication complexity of our method is never worse than the ones of the existing methods since the second-order heterogeneity Î¶ğœ\zeta is bounded by two times the smoothness Lğ¿L of local objectives444For the details, see Assumption 1 in Section 2.

Results 1: Effect of the heterogeneity.  Here, we investigate the effect of the heterogeneity on the convergence speed of the algorithms. To clarify the pure effect of the heterogeneity, we fixed the local computation budget â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} to 1,02410241,024, which was the largest one in our experiments. Figure 2 shows the comparison of the best-achieved train loss and test accuracy in 3,00030003,000 communication rounds against heterogeneity parameter qğ‘q. From this, we can see that the convergence speed of the local methods deteriorated as heterogeneity parameter qğ‘q increased. Particularly, the degree of the performance degradation of L-SGD and SCAFFOLD was serious. In contrast, this phenomenon was not observed for non-local methods, because the convergence rates of non-local methods do not depend on heterogeneity Î¶ğœ\zeta as in Table 1. Importantly, even for the largest qğ‘q, BVR-L-SGD significantly outperformed the other methods.

Results 2: Effect of the local computation budget size.  Now, we examine the effect of the size of the local computation budget â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} to the convergence speed. For this purpose, we fixed heterogeneity parameter qğ‘q to the smallest one. Figure 3 shows the comparison of the best-achieved train loss and test accuracy against local computation budget â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}. We can see that the local methods improved their performances as local computation budget â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} increased, but non-local methods did not. This is because local methods can potentially achieve a smaller communication complexity than 1/Îµ1ğœ€1/\varepsilon by increasing â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} for small Î¶ğœ\zeta, but non-local methods can not break the barrier of 1/Îµ1ğœ€1/\varepsilon for any â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} as in Table 1.
